title: Don‚Äôt Let Summer Stress Destroy Your Landscape‚ÄîFertilize & Protect Now!

content.text: Don‚Äôt Let Summer Stress Destroy Your Landscape‚ÄîFertilize & Protect Now!
The intense heat and dryness of Colorado summers can wreak havoc on your trees and landscape. July and August are critical months to take action!

items: Stimulate deep root growth to find water.
Prepare plants for a strong fall recovery.
July and August bring insects like Japanese Beetles and Spider Mites.

content.text: Our custom-blended fertilizer with insect repellent penetrates soil fast‚Äîprotecting your landscape for the toughest summer months.
Spots are filling fast for mid-summer service. Book your treatment now and keep your yard healthy through fall.

title: The Beetles Are Back: How to Protect Your Colorado Trees This Spring Before It‚Äôs Too Late
author: A Quality Tree Care

content.text: The Beetles Are Back: How to Protect Your Colorado Trees This Spring Before It‚Äôs Too Late

As the mountains wake up from winter, something far more dangerous than melting snow is on the move‚Äîbark beetles. From the mountain pine beetle to the spruce and Douglas-fir beetles, these tiny invaders are ready to attack trees across Colorado‚Äôs high country.
If you live in or near the mountains, spring is your only window to take action before the damage is done.
üö® Why Spring Is Your Last Line of Defense

By late April and early May, bark beetles begin emerging from trees they infested last summer. As soon as daytime temperatures hit 50¬∞F, they take flight in search of new trees to colonize. If you wait until the damage is visible, it‚Äôs already too late.
‚è≥ Now is the time to inspect, treat, and protect your trees.

content.heading: üêû Mountain Pine Beetle
list: Leaves behind pitch tubes and sawdust at the base

content.heading: üêû Spruce Beetle
list: Often invisible until crowns turn brown

content.text: üõ†Ô∏è What You Must Do This Spring

items.title: ‚úÖ 1. Schedule a Professional Tree Assessment
items.text: If you‚Äôre unsure whether your trees are vulnerable, get a licensed arborist on-site now. Early detection is critical. üóì Call today to book your spring tree health check.

items.title: ‚úÖ 2. Apply Preventive Treatments Before Beetle Flight
items.text: Protect high-value trees with systemic insecticides or bark sprays. These must be applied before beetles emerge‚Äîusually late May through July depending on elevation. üíâ Don‚Äôt delay‚Äîonce beetles bore in, chemical treatments are useless.

items.title: ‚úÖ 3. Remove and Destroy Infested Trees
items.text: If you suspect a tree is already infested, have it removed before new beetles emerge. Chipping, solarizing, or burning infested wood will prevent further spread. ü™ì Contact us for fast, compliant tree removal and disposal.

items.title: ‚úÖ 4. Diversify and Defend Your Landscape
items.text: Consider planting mixed species to reduce future outbreak risk and make your landscape more resilient.

content.text: üå≤ Don‚Äôt Let a Beetle Decide the Fate of Your Forest
Colorado‚Äôs trees are irreplaceable‚Äîbut they‚Äôre not invincible. With drought and warming temperatures, bark beetles are thriving like never before.
üéØ Take action this spring to protect your investment, your property, and the health of Colorado‚Äôs forests.
